name: U.S. Coast Guard Cutter Mackinaw
description: U.S. Coast Guard Cutter MACKINAW WAGB-83 is known as the “Queen of the Great Lakes” and “The Largest Icebreaker on the Great Lakes”. She was built during World War II to meet the heavy demands of war materials and transportation during the winter months.

description: A working exhibit and a hub of activity on the Museum Campus. Classes and programs are offered year-round including boat building, small craft restorations, presentations, and annual maintenance of the Museum’s exhibits and on-water fleet.

name: Herbert Van Oort Boathouse
description: Among the finest collections of wooden rescue boats used by the U.S. Lifesaving Service and Coast Guard. The museum is home to four fully restored rescue boats ranging from the Merryman, an 1881 rescue boat, to a 1950s 36ft. motor lifeboat.

Pointe Aux Barques Lifesaving Station
description: Established near this site in 1875, decommissioned in 1956. Six Surfmen perished on April 23, 1880 while responding to a distress signal from the lumber scow J.H MAGRUDER.
Established near this site in 1875, decommissioned in 1956. Six Surfmen perished on April 23, 1880 while responding to a distress signal from the lumber scow J.H MAGRUDER.

name: USS Silversides
description: Credited with sinking 23 major Japanese ships (the third highest total for any U.S. Navy Submarine) for an approximate tonnage of 90,080. Silversides received the Presidential Unit Citation and 12 Battle Stars for her wartime service.

name: United States Coast Guard Cutter McLane
description: During WWII conducted convoy escorts, anti-submarine patrols, and rescue of ships and aircraft in distress. Credited with the sinking of a Japanese Submarine in July 1942 and a multiple-person rescue of a downed aircraft in February 1943.

name: USCG South Haven Outbuilding
description: The last surviving structure of the South Haven Life Saving Station. The small shed hosts the knot tying exhibit.
